content.text: To ensure valid, reliable, and fair assessment practices that inform teaching, improve student learning, provide accurate feedback to students and parents, and maintain integrity across both Cambridge and Indonesian assessment requirements.

Eduversal schools implement a balanced assessment philosophy that includes Assessment FOR Learning (formative assessment to support instruction), Assessment AS Learning (student self-reflection and goal setting), and Assessment OF Learning (summative assessment to measure achievement against standards).

content.title: Core Beliefs
items: Assessment FOR Learning: Used during learning to diagnose needs, adjust instruction, and provide feedback.
Assessment AS Learning: Students reflect on their own learning, set goals, and monitor progress.
Assessment OF Learning: Measures achievement at the end of a unit/term/course.

content.title: Guiding Principles
items: Standards-Referenced: All assessments aligned to clear learning objectives.
Fair and Equitable: Assessments accessible to all students with accommodations as needed.
Transparent: Assessment criteria shared with students before assessment.
Timely and Actionable Feedback: Feedback provided promptly and is specific and constructive.
Integrated with Instruction: Assessment data used to inform teaching decisions.

content.text: Eduversal Partner Schools employ a comprehensive assessment system balancing multiple types and purposes.
Assessment Types include formative, summative, diagnostic, and standardized assessments.
Purpose: Coordinate assessments across subjects and grades to avoid student overload and ensure adequate time for teaching, learning, and feedback.

content.title: Exam Week Protocols
items: 2 weeks' notice: Exam schedule published.
Study guides provided: Teachers distribute review materials.
No new content: Week before exams reserved for review.
Timetable staggered: Maximum 2 exams per day per student.
Prompt marking: Teachers aim to return marked exams within 1 week.

content.text: Purpose: Provide ongoing feedback during learning to help students improve before summative assessments.

content.title: High-Impact Formative Assessment Techniques
items: Exit Tickets: Brief responses at the end of lessons.
Think-Pair-Share: Students discuss questions with partners.
Thumbs Up/Down: Quick checks of understanding.
Draft Reviews: Feedback on drafts before final submission.
Observation and Anecdotal Notes: Teacher notes on student understanding.
Self-Assessment and Reflection: Students assess their own work.

content.text: Feedback Guidelines: Effective feedback should be specific, actionable, timely, balanced, and goal-oriented.
Purpose: Measure student achievement against standards at the end of learning periods.

content.title: Types of Summative Assessments
items: Traditional Tests/Exams: Multiple choice, short answer, essay questions.
Performance Tasks: Demonstrate skills or create products.
Projects: Extended inquiry or creation over several weeks.
Portfolios: Curated collection of student work showing growth.

content.text: Assessment Quality Checklist: Ensures alignment, coverage, validity, reliability, fairness, clarity, and adequate time.
Moderation is the process through which teachers collaboratively review student work to ensure that marking is fair, accurate, and consistently aligned to agreed standards.

content.title: Moderation Process (Step-by-Step)
items: Pre-Assessment Standardization: Select anchor samples and mark independently.
During-Marking Moderation: Exchange scripts for blind re-marking.
Post-Marking Moderation: Review grade distribution and provide feedback.

content.text: Moderation for Cambridge Coursework: Internal moderation required before submitting marks to Cambridge.
Academic grades reflect student achievement against curriculum standards. Character and effort indicators are reported separately.

content.title: Cambridge Subjects: Grading Scale
items: Official Cambridge grades: A*, A, B, C, D, E, F, G, U.
School-based grades: Predicted grades or percentage/letter grades aligned to Cambridge standards.

content.title: Indonesian National Subjects: Grading Scale
items: Scale: 0-100 (percentage).
Descriptors: 90-100 = Sangat Baik (Excellent), 80-89 = Baik (Good), below 70 = Kurang (Needs Improvement).

content.text: Purpose: Communicate student progress to students and parents clearly, accurately, and in ways that support continued learning.

content.title: Report Card Schedule
items: Mid-Term Progress Reports: Week 8-10 of each term.
End-of-Term Report Cards: Week 20 (Term 1) and Week 24 (Term 2).

content.title: Report Card Components
items: Student and School Information.
Cambridge Subjects Section.
Indonesian National Subjects Section.
Profil Pelajar Pancasila Competencies.
Character and Effort Grades.
Attendance.
Co-Curricular Participation.
Homeroom Teacher Overall Comment.

content.text: Purpose: Complement written reports with face-to-face dialogue, answer parent questions, co-create support plans.

content.title: Conference Schedule
items: Term 1: Week 20.
Mid-Year: Week 10 of Term 2 (optional).
Term 2: Week 24.

content.title: Conference Structure
items: Welcome and Relationship Building.
Review Academic Progress.
Social-Emotional and Character Development.
Goal Setting and Action Plan.
Closing.

subsections.title: Use of Assessment Data to Inform Instruction

content.text: Purpose: Assessment is not an endpoint; it's a tool to improve teaching and learning.

content.title: Data Analysis Process (Professional Learning Communities)
items: Review Data: Identify patterns in student performance.
Analyze Root Causes: Determine why students struggled.
Plan Interventions: Develop strategies for whole class, small groups, and individuals.
Share Strategies: Collaborate and share successful practices.
Set Goals for Next Meeting.

content.text: Purpose: Cultivate a culture of honesty, original thinking, and proper attribution; prevent and address academic dishonesty.

content.title: Academic Integrity Policy
items: Plagiarism: Using someone else's work without citation.
Cheating: Using unauthorized materials during assessments.
Collusion: Unauthorized collaboration on individual assignments.

content.title: Prevention Strategies
items: Explicit Teaching: Lessons on citation and ethical research.
Assignment Design: Unique prompts and process-based assignments.
Technology Use: Plagiarism detection software.

content.title: Detection and Response
items: Gather Evidence: Document concerns and run checks.
Private Conversation with Student: Discuss evidence.
Determine Violation Level and Consequence.

content.text: Principle: Fair assessment means giving every student opportunity to demonstrate what they know and can do.

content.title: Accommodations (Do Not Change Standards)
items: Extended time and frequent breaks.
Separate quiet room or small group setting.
Presentation adjustments like enlarged print or read-aloud.

content.title: Differentiated Assessment (Adjust to Readiness/Interest)
items: Choice Boards: Students choose how to demonstrate learning.
Tiered Assessments: Different complexity levels for the same objective.
Product Options: Allow students to choose format for assignments.

content.text: Purpose: Compare student performance to external standards, track growth over time, inform school improvement.

content.title: EASE (Evaluation of Achievement Standardized Exam)
items: Administered 4x/year to all students Grades 1-12.
Measures literacy, numeracy, and subject-specific content.
Used for formative/diagnostic purposes, not individual grades.

content.title: Cambridge Progression Tests
items: Optional diagnostic tests for Grades 7-9.
Assess readiness for IGCSE and identify strengths/gaps.

content.title: ANBK (Asesmen Nasional Berbasis Komputer)
items: Indonesian national assessment for Grades 5, 8, 11.
Measures literacy, numeracy, character, and learning environment.

subsections.title: Reporting to Universities and Transcript Management

content.text: Purpose: Provide accurate, comprehensive academic records for university admission, scholarships, and transfers.

content.title: Official Transcripts
items: Includes student and school information, academic record, standardized test results, GPA, and graduation date.

content.title: Predicted Grades for University Applications
items: Professional teacher judgments indicating likely grades for final exams.
Shared with universities but not typically with students/parents.

content.title: Letters of Recommendation
items: Qualitative assessment of student's academic abilities and character.
Requested by students and submitted directly to universities.

subsections.title: Assessment Policy Review and Continuous Improvement

content.text: Purpose: Assessment practices evolve based on research, student needs, and stakeholder feedback.

content.title: Annual Assessment Policy Review Process
items: Data Review: Analyze student achievement trends and assessment effectiveness.
Stakeholder Feedback: Surveys from teachers, students, and parents.
Research and Best Practices: Review educational research and benchmark against other schools.
Identify Improvements: Update grading scales, rubrics, and reporting formats.

content.text: The Appraisal Program evaluates teaching quality through classroom observations and evaluations across multiple domains.

content.title: Evidence
items: Appraisal observation forms and rubrics.
Post-appraisal meeting notes.
Teacher improvement plans.

content.text: All assessment data, records, and reports are handled confidentially in accordance with regulations.

content.title: Policy and Procedures
items: Assessment Policy.
Academic Integrity Policy.
Accommodations and Differentiation Guidelines.

content.title: Assessment Design
items: Sample assessments from each subject/grade.
Assessment blueprints.
Moderation cover sheets.

content.text: This section aligns with Cambridge Assessment Standards, Indonesian Curriculum Standards, CIS Standards, WASC Category B, and Eduversal SLOs.
